article.title: The Fierz convergence criterion: a controlled approach to strongly-interacting systems with small embedded clusters

choices: The energy bands of the Hubbard model.
The charge and spin density waves in the Hubbard model.
The cluster geometries used in the cluster TRILEX method.
The Fermi surface of the two-dimensional Hubbard model.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main conclusion that can be drawn from Figure 2 about the cluster TRILEX method?
choices: The self-energy becomes insensitive to the Fierz parameter α for large cluster sizes.
GW+EDMFT gives accurate results for all values of the Fierz parameter α.
The self-energy always has a strong dependence on the Fierz parameter α.
The imaginary part of the self-energy is always zero.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 illustrate about the dependence of ReΣ(k,iω₀) on the Fierz parameter α?
choices: The dependence on α is independent of the cluster size Nc.
The α-dependence is weak for all cluster sizes Nc.
For Nc = 4, the results show an extended plateau, indicating weak dependence on α.
The QMC results match the Nc = 1 results for all values of α.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 6 reveal about the momentum dependence of the three-leg vertex function?
choices: The vertex is completely momentum independent.
The vertex displays strong momentum dependence at both low and high frequencies.
The momentum dependence is primarily significant at low Matsubara frequencies, particularly in the charge channel.
The momentum dependence is only significant in the spin channel.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 5 demonstrate about the performance of cluster TRILEX and GW+EDMFT at point C (strong-coupling regime)?
choices: Both methods accurately capture the self-energy in the strong-coupling regime.
Cluster TRILEX with Nc = 4 shows good agreement with the DCA benchmark, while GW+EDMFT deviates significantly.
GW+EDMFT performs better than cluster TRILEX in the strong-coupling regime.
The self-energy is purely imaginary in the strong-coupling regime.
